entry.title: Combined summary - BIP: register with IANA for bitcoin/cryptocoin port numbers
entry.summary: On January 2, 2014, Troy Benjegerdes sent an email with three questions concerning Bitcoin. The first question asks why Bitcoin typically runs on port 8333. The second question is about why Bitcoin does not appear on the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) website's list of service names and port numbers. Lastly, Benjegerdes inquires about how someone from the Bitcoin Foundation can fill out a form to request an assigned port. It is unclear what prompted these questions, but it appears that Benjegerdes is curious about the technical aspects of Bitcoin and its use of ports.In response to his questions, someone has stated that they have requested an assignment for Bitcoin. It is unknown who made this request or if it was successful. Overall, the email provides insight into the technical details of Bitcoin and the process for obtaining an assigned port. However, without more context, it is difficult to understand the significance of these questions and why they were asked in the first place.The following questions have been raised about Bitcoin's port number and its visibility on IANA's website. Firstly, it has been noted that Bitcoin usually runs on port 8333, but the reason for this is unknown. Secondly, Bitcoin does not appear on IANA's list of assigned port numbers, leading to confusion about its legitimacy. Thirdly, there are queries about how someone from the Bitcoin foundation can request an assigned port through IANA's form. Lastly, the process for new cryptocurrencies to obtain default port numbers and P2P network identifier 'magic numbers' is also being questioned. These issues need to be addressed in order to clarify Bitcoin's status and to provide guidance for future cryptocurrencies.In an email on January 3, 2014, Troy Benjegerdes poses several questions related to Bitcoin's use of port 8333 and its absence from the IANA registry. He asks what needs to happen for someone from the Bitcoin Foundation to fill out the form asking for an assigned port, and what the process should be for new cryptocurrencies to get default port numbers and P2P network identifier 'magic numbers'. IANA normally registers ports with conservation in mind, and two unassigned ports (8333 and 18333) are currently available. It would be ideal to have separate ports for the main net and test net, but only one may be granted due to conservation considerations. The possibility of multiplexing traffic over a single port is also raised. The email includes a list of other assigned and unassigned ports, and it's noted that a slew of alternative coins reserving ports could raise eyebrows.The discussion is about having one or two ports for Bitcoin, one for the main network and another for the test network. It is suggested that if conservation is an issue, the testnet port can be forgone as there is no logic to multiplexing them since they are entirely separate networks. In case the port is already in use, Bitcoin can run on any other available port and announce it. There isn't even an argument for convenience since most users don't specify nodes and can specify a port when necessary. The issue of alt coins reserving ports is not a concern for Bitcoin and it may be realistic for Bitcoin to allocate one or two ports for its use.
